title: R42644
content: The Administration requested $39.510 billion for DHS in FY2013, a slight decrease from the previous year. The Senate Committee on Appropriations approved a net discretionary appropriation of $39.514 million for DHS, excluding funds for overseas operations and disaster relief. The Senate-reported bill for DHS in FY2013 would have provided slightly less than the Administration's request, with adjustments to discretionary spending caps. The House passed H.R. 5855 with amendments, resulting in a net discretionary appropriation of $39,114 million for DHS. Increases were proposed for various DHS activities, including Border Security Fencing and Urban Search and Rescue Response programs. The President signed H.J.Res. 117 into law as a continuing resolution on September 28, 2012. The President signed H.J.Res. 117 into law as P.L. 112-175 on September 28, 2012, allowing the federal government to continue operations until March 27, 2013, at an annualized rate of $1.047 trillion. H.R. 933 was signed into law as P.L. 113-6 on March 26, 2013, providing $39.646 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority for the Department of Homeland Security, with $38.348 billion available after across-the-board cuts. After sequestration, $39.646 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority was available for DHS from P.L. 113-6. Data sources include President's Budget Documents, Congressional Budget Justifications, and Appropriations bills. Post-sequester funding levels are from the DHS Fiscal Year 2013 Post-Sequestration Operating Plan. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 transferred functions, funding, and personnel to the Department of Homeland Security. Appropriations for DHS are organized into five titles, including OSEM, USM, CBP, ICE, TSA, USCG, and Secret Service. Amounts in the report are in budget authority and rounded to the nearest million. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 transferred functions, funding, and personnel to the Department of Homeland Security, which is organized into five titles for appropriations. These titles cover various agencies such as CBP, ICE, TSA, USCG, Secret Service, NPPD, OHA, FEMA, USCIS, S&T, and FLETC. The structure of the appropriations bill may vary between House and Senate versions, with additional titles added as needed for special issues. The FY2013 appropriations bills had parallel structures with some differences in subcomponents and accounts noted. Congress determines budget authority through a two-stage process, with 302(a) allocations setting overall spending totals and 302(b) allocations allocating funds among subcommittees for appropriations bills. The 302(b) allocations for appropriations bills must not exceed the 302(a) discretionary allocation to enforce budget discipline. Adjustments can be made by the Appropriations Committee during the year. The FY2012 appropriations bills were impacted by the Budget Control Act, which set spending caps for FY2012 and FY2013. For FY2013, a separate cap of $686 billion was set for security spending, with all other spending capped. The Budget Control Act set spending caps for FY2012 and FY2013, with a separate cap of $686 billion for security spending. All other spending was capped at $361 billion out of the total of $1.047 trillion. The BCA allows for adjustments to cover funding for various purposes, and triggered automatic spending reductions when deficit reduction legislation was not enacted. The Budget Control Act of 2011 triggered automatic spending reductions when deficit reduction legislation was not enacted by January 15, 2012. This process involved sequestration and lower discretionary spending caps, with the Office of Management and Budget implementing across-the-board spending cuts to achieve equal budget reductions from both defense and nondefense funding. The American Taxpayer Relief Act made changes to the procedures, delaying the implementation of the joint committee sequester until March 1, 2013. The joint committee sequester was delayed until March 1, 2013, with a $24 billion reduction in the dollar amount. Statutory caps on discretionary spending for FY2013 and FY2014 were lowered. President Obama ordered the sequester's implementation, with OMB reporting budget authority cancellations at the program level. The Department of Homeland Security's headquarters is spread across 45 locations in the Washington, DC area, leading to inefficiencies and increased costs. The Department of Homeland Security approved a $3.4 billion master plan with the General Services Administration to create a new headquarters at St Elizabeths in Anacostia, aiming to unify functions and reduce inefficiencies. $1.4 billion is funded through DHS, and $2 billion through GSA. $1,366 million has been invested in the project so far, with Phase 1A nearing completion for a new Coast Guard headquarters facility. Some DHS functions in the DC area will not move to the new facility, with efforts to consolidate offices for cost savings on lease expenses. CBP is responsible for security at ports of entry along the border, with a focus on preventing terrorism. They inspect people and goods to determine authorization for entry, enforcing over 400 laws to prevent illegal entries. CBP's major programs include Border Security Inspections, Trade Facilitation, Border Security and Control, Air and Marine Interdiction, Automation Modernization, Border Security Fencing, Facilities Management, and more. The Department of Homeland Security's Customs and Border Protection (CBP) is responsible for security at ports of entry along the border, focusing on preventing terrorism and enforcing over 400 laws to prevent illegal entries. CBP's major programs include Automation Modernization, Border Security Fencing, Facilities Management, and immigration and customs user Fee Accounts. Various policy issues related to CBP were discussed during the FY2013 appropriations cycle. The US-VISIT program, CBP staffing, reimbursement authority, customs user fees, border surveillance technology, and cargo security are key components of the entry-exit system that tracks the arrival and departure of foreign visitors to the United States. Biographic and biometric data are collected and stored in databases to help identify potential risks. The entry-exit system in the United States collects biometric data from non-citizens entering the country but not when they exit. The President's FY2013 budget did not include funding for a biometric exit system, focusing instead on an enhanced biographic exit program and a U.S.-Canadian entry-exit system. Passenger manifest data is checked against various databases to identify overstays and potential risks. The U.S. entry-exit system checks data against various databases to identify overstays and high-priority individuals for follow-up investigations. Citizenship and Immigration Canada provides biometric records of third country nationals entering Canada for U.S. exit records. Congress has pushed for a comprehensive exit system, and the system's organizational structure has changed multiple times since its creation in 2003 as the US-VISIT Program under DHS. The US-VISIT Program, initially under DHS' BTS, underwent reorganization by former Secretary Chertoff, moving to a proposed Screening Coordination Office that was never funded. It became a stand-alone office in FY2006, transferred to NPPD in FY2008. In FY2013, a proposed move to CBP and ICE was not fully supported by Congress. The House-passed bill would transfer $73 million to CBP and ICE for entry-exit policy and overstay analysis, leaving $191 million for US-VISIT funding in a new Office of Biometric Identity Management within NPPD. The Senate-reported bill recommended transferring US-VISIT to CBP as a stand-alone appropriation. P.L. 113-6 replaced US-VISIT with the Office of Biometric Identity Management. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is proposing a strategy to control the Southwest Border using technology for surveillance. ICE focuses on enforcing immigration and customs laws in the U.S., including investigating violations and removing deportable aliens. ICE enforces immigration and customs laws, investigates violations, removes deportable aliens, combats terrorist financing, money laundering, and enforces export laws. The Administration requested $5,332 million in net budget authority for ICE in FY2013, a decrease of $218 million from FY2012. Federal government spending involves a process starting with budget authority enactment by Congress, followed by fund obligation and outlays. Budget authority is determined through appropriations acts or direct spending legislation. The Antideficiency Act prohibits federal agencies from overspending. The Antideficiency Act prohibits federal agencies from obligating more funds than the budget authority enacted by Congress, which may be indefinite. Budget authority can be one-year, multi-year, or no-year, with obligations incurred when agencies employ personnel, enter contracts, or receive services. Outlays are the funds actually spent during the fiscal year, and may not always match the budget authority enacted. Budget authority allows federal agencies to incur obligations and authorize payments from the Treasury. It consists of discretionary and mandatory spending, with discretionary funds appropriated yearly by Congress and mandatory spending provided in budget authority and resulting outlays. The federal government's budget authority includes discretionary and mandatory spending, with discretionary funds appropriated yearly by Congress. Mandatory spending, also known as direct spending, consists of budget authority provided in laws other than appropriation acts. Offsetting collections are funds collected by the government as part of business-type transactions and are not counted as revenue. DHS net discretionary budget authority is composed of discretionary spending minus any fee or fund collections that offset discretionary spending. The DHS budget includes mandatory entitlement programs like the Secret Service and Coast Guard retired pay accounts, funded by permanent or annual appropriations. Additionally, there are offsetting Trust and Public Enterprise Funds that are not appropriated by Congress. This funding is used to calculate the gross budget authority.
